awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Self-Assembly of Zwitterionic Amphiphilic Copolymers for Membranes with Sharp, Tunable Pore Size
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER 1553661-Asatekin.

Membrane filtration is energy efficient, simple, scalable, and a key technology for generating clean, safe water and for preventing water pollution. Most commercially available membranes are composed of a handful of polymers, and are limited in the types of separations they can perform. This project aims to build an integrated research and education plan centered on developing novel membranes with new capabilities by designing polymers that self-assemble to form nanostructures. Specifically, this research will focus on controlling the pore size of a novel family of membranes with high flux, exceptional fouling resistance, and sharp size-based selectivity, prepared by coating zwitterion-containing amphiphilic copolymers on porous supports. This research will lead to the development of improved membranes for separations underserved by existing technologies such as peptide separations and textile wastewater treatment. It will create a link between polymer structure and membrane performance that will enable the rational design of membrane materials for specific applications. The research will be fully integrated with a system of educational activities through the involvement of students at multiple stages in developing and performing outreach activities on polymer science and separations. The team will work closely with Tufts Center for Engineering Education and Outreach (CEEO) to develop new outreach activities for K-12 students. The activity ideas will be initiated as term projects in the PI's courses for undergraduate and graduate students. They will be tested in summer workshops for girls in Malden, MA and also implemented in local schools through the Tufts Student Teacher Outreach Mentorship Program (STOMP), and disseminated through the STOMP Network. 

This project aims to build an integrated research and education plan centered on designing polymeric materials that self-assemble into functional nanostructures that lead to the desired membrane functionality (e.g. selectivity, fouling resistance), and on discovering fundamental relationships that correlate polymer chemistry and architecture, self-assembled nanostructure, and function in membrane applications. The specific research objective of this project is to understand how the chemical structure and molecular architecture of copolymers with hydrophobic and zwitterionic groups, and their processing methods, affect (1) their self-assembled nanostructure and (2) their performance as membrane materials in selective separations. The team aims to control the pore size of these membranes by varying the polymer architecture and processing, and to develop fundamental structure-property-function relationships that serve as design rules for polymeric membrane materials with tunable, precise and monodispersed pore size. For this purpose, the team will synthesize amphiphilic copolymers that combine hydrophobic and zwitterionic monomers in random, comb and star-block architectures. How these materials self-assemble will be studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray scattering. Membranes will be made by coating porous supports with these polymers, and the pore size will be determined by filtration experiments. The pore size, permeability and fouling resistance of membranes will be correlated with the self-assembled morphology. The results will be used to compile design rules or a toolkit for the rational design of membrane materials targeted at specific separations that derive their permeability, selectivity and fouling resistance from their self-assembled structure. The research will be fully integrated with several educational, outreach and mentorship activities, such as the development of outreach activities for K-12 students that introduce concepts in polymer science, self-assembly and separations, incorporation of proposed research into undergraduate lab courses and classes, and involvement of undergraduate students in research.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF CAREER project aimed to understand the separation performance of zwitterionic amphiphilic copolymers (ZACs) when used as membrane selective layers, and to explore how the chemical structure and architecture of these copolymers can be manipulated to control membrane selectivity. ZAC-based membranes are manufactured in a simple scalable manner, by coating a thin layer of the polymer on a porous support. They also exhibit unmatched fouling resistance, enabling their use in treating complex feed streams high in oil and organic macromolecules.Through this project, the team developed approaches to control the effective pore size and solute selectivity of ZAC-based membranes, accessing separations that current membranes cannot achieve due to limitations in selectivity and fouling resistance. As such, this project served to develop and expand this family of novel membrane materials, understand their separation capabilities, and link the nanoscale self-assembled structure of ZACs with membrane performance. 

During this work, the team documented the self-assembly of random/statistical ZACs (rZACs) to create a network of hydrophilic, zwitterionic "nanochannels". They also showed that membranes prepared by coating a thin layer of a rZAC onto a porous support exhibit an effective pore size similar to the hydrated/swollen nanochannel size for the copolymer. Interestingly, the effective pore sizes of membranes made from ZACs with various zwitterionic monomer chemistries were very similar. The team found that this was related with the fact that, in water, these rZACs all swell similarly, resulting in the expansion of the channels to a similar size. Zwitterion chemistry, however, was a significant factor in fouling resistance of these membranes. 

The team then developed novel cross-linkable ZACs (X-ZACs). Cross-linking prevented the swelling of these nanochannels, enabling access to effective pore sizes <1 nm. These membranes with very small pores, lined with zwitterions, were found to exhibit exceptional selectivity between anions. Further study of their selectivity showed that these membranes can even separate anions of similar size and charge such as F- and Cl-, with the highest separation factors reported in the literature to date. Transport analysis showed that this capability is associated with differences in zwitterion-ion interactions, changing the partitioning of ions into the nanochannels. 

This project also evolved to the exploration of amphiphilic polyampholytes and amphiphilic polyelectrolyte complexes, which are copolymers with highly incompatible repeat units like ZACs, but have a wider range of chemical structures accessible through simple, scalable chemistry. 

In addition, the PI and project team worked with the Tufts University Center for Engineering Education (CEEO) to develop engineering outreach activities for K-12 students that focus on chemical engineering. The team ran two free summer camps for ~20 middle school girls each from diverse backgrounds underrepresented in STEM, with the involvement of chemical engineering undergraduate and graduate students as volunteers. While these camps were stopped due to the Covid19 pandemic, the team adapted and used them again in summer 2022 in a summer camp organized for 7-13 year old students from backgrounds underrepresented in STEM. The group expects to continue running these activities in outreach events in the future.

Overall, this project fully or partially supported 19 published peer-reviewed manuscripts, many conference presentations by the PI and graduate students, as well as many invited seminars given by the PI. It provided training opportunities to several graduate and undergraduate students, more than half of whom were women.  

Technologies developed through this grant were licensed by ZwitterCo, Inc., a start-up formed to commercialize r-ZAC-based membranes for treating extremely challenging wastewater streams (COI note: Dr. Asatekin owns a small equity in ZwitterCo and serves as its Senior Scientific Advisor. She has an active FCOI management plan.). Since its founding in 2018, ZwitterCo has scaled up the manufacture of one ZAC-based membrane chemistry and has installed it in many locations, treating wastewater streams previously deemed unfilterable and enabling the reuse of water and nutrients in farms, food processing plants, and other locations.
